meta.title: Operational Geometry: Comprehensive Glossary
meta.subtitle: Definitions for Operations-Primary Mathematics
meta.purpose: Formal vocabulary reference for operations-primary mathematics framework
meta.author: Zelenka_D_D

operation.definition: The ontologically primitive notion; operations generate objects as stable invariants, not performed on pre-existing objects.

substrate.definition: The continuous field capable of supporting operations; an active medium with coherence capacity, memory retention, and resistance to threading. Ontological foundation.

threading.definition: The act of performing operations on substrate, leaving traces (memory) and creating paths through configuration space; threading depth corresponds to operational accumulation.

configuration.definition: A possible arrangement of substrate after operations; temporary stabilities in ongoing operational processes, not static snapshots.

configuration_space.definition: Space of all possible substrate configurations; each point represents distinct threading arrangement; operations are paths through this space.

coherence.definition: The degree to which operational patterns reinforce rather than interfere; substrate's ability to maintain consistent threading patterns. Measure of structural stability.

coherence_capacity.definition: Substrate's maximum ability to maintain consistent threading patterns; finite capacity limits instantiable mathematical structures. Physical constraint on mathematics.

coherence_threshold.definition: Critical operational complexity beyond which substrate cannot maintain consistent threading; quantum decoherence and computational intractability. Boundary of realizability.

memory.definition: Accumulated operational history encoded in substrate; persistent structural changes from operations, not storage of information.

attractor.definition: Stable configuration toward which operations converge; fixed points where f(x*) = x*. Mathematical constants (φ, π, e) are attractors in their respective operational spaces.

axiom_operational_priority.definition: Operations are ontologically prior to objects; objects emerge as stable invariants under repeated operations. Foundational claim of operations-primary mathematics.

axiom_substrate_reality.definition: There exists a substrate capable of supporting operations with intrinsic properties constraining admissible operations. The medium in which threading occurs.

axiom_geometric_emergence.definition: Spatial structure (distance, dimension, continuity) emerges from operational substrate threading, not pre-existing. Space is constructed through operations, not given a priori.

axiom_teleological_constraints.definition: Operations are directed toward forms satisfying coherence, stability, efficiency, and beauty constraints; emergent structures are filtered by purposiveness. Not random drift but directed evolution.

axiom_finite_physical_realizability.definition: Physical substrates have finite coherence capacity, finite memory capacity, and finite operational rate. Constrains which mathematical structures can be physically instantiated.

operational_gradient.definition: Intrinsic directional structure of substrate making some operations easier than others; cannot be eliminated, reflects fundamental asymmetries.

operational_potential.definition: Minimal effort to reach state x from initial state.

operational_cost.definition: Effort/resources required to execute operation sequence.

operational_flow.definition: Natural direction operations follow due to gradient; geodesics in configuration space; efficient algorithms work with flow. Follows steepest descent of potential.

operational_depth.definition: Number of sequential threading operations performed; time as operational count, not duration. Measures complexity of reaching configuration.

operational_width.definition: Number of parallel threading branches; simultaneous operational possibilities; nondeterministic computation dimension. Measures branching factor.

operational_locality.definition: Constraint that operations directly thread only nearby substrate regions; non-local effects require mediated paths. Fundamental causality principle.

iogt.definition: Composable operations induce intrinsic gradients of difficulty; forward construction and reverse reconstruction are generically asymmetric. Foundational theorem of operational geometry.

composition_amplification.definition: Asymmetry magnifies under operational composition; ε-forward-easy can require exp(n)-reverse-hard. Explains exponential gaps in complexity.

gradient_aligned.definition: Operations proceeding with (downhill along) the operational gradient; polynomial cost, includes evaluation and verification.

gradient_opposed.definition: Operations proceeding against (uphill) the operational gradient; exponential cost, includes search and inversion.

iot.definition: Exponential operational cost cannot be perfectly conserved across time-parallelism trade; overhead factor (1+c) is irreducible.

irreducible_overhead.definition: Minimum unavoidable coordination cost in parallel operations; cannot be eliminated by algorithmic optimization. (1+c) factor in IOT.

coordination_cost.definition: Extra operational overhead required to synchronize parallel branches; arises from substrate limitations.

function.definition: Operational mapping; rule threading configurations from one domain into another; deterministic operation sequence.

domain.definition: Operational input space; configurations on which function can operate; where threading begins.

range.definition: Operational output space; configurations function can produce; where threading ends.

composition.definition: Sequential function application; threading one operation after another.

iteration.definition: Repeated operational application; threading same operation multiple times; controlled operational repetition.

recursion.definition: Self-referential threading; operations invoking themselves as sub-operations; operational self-similarity. Enables infinite structures from finite rules.

fixed_point.definition: Configuration unchanged by operation; x* satisfying f(x*) = x*. Attractors are fixed points of iteration.

limit.definition: Operational convergence; configuration approached as threading depth increases; asymptotic attractor of operational sequences.

derivative.definition: Rate of operational change; how fast threading produces new configurations; instantaneous threading velocity.

integral.definition: Accumulated operational effect; total structural change from continuous threading; sums infinitesimal operations.

addition.definition: Sequential threading; performing one operation after another; operational composition along single dimension.

multiplication.definition: Repeated threading; iterating an operation; operational iteration creating amplification.

exponentiation.definition: Iterated multiplication; operations on operations; meta-operational counting of iteration depth.

division.definition: Inverse of multiplication; boundary operation; undefined at 0. Creates rational structure.

modular_arithmetic.definition: Cyclic operation; periodic residue classes; bounded structure.

factorial.definition: Cascading multiplication; product of all threading operations up to n; measures permutation space size.

zero.definition: Additive identity; operation that changes nothing; configuration before any counting operation begins.

one.definition: Multiplicative identity; minimal threading; single operational step; unit by which all operations are measured.

number.definition: Operational invariant of counting and grouping operations; repeatable procedures yielding same structural pattern. Fundamental mathematical object.

naturals.definition: Generated by +1 operation from 0; exploratory stage of number system evolution. Foundational for arithmetic.

integers.definition: ℕ closed under subtraction; includes negative threading (reverse operations). Fundamental ring structure.

rationals.definition: ℤ closed under division (except by 0); field of fractions; periodic decimal expansions. Countable infinite structure.

reals.definition: ℚ closed under limits; completion via Cauchy sequences or Dedekind cuts; continuous line. Uncountable structure.

complex.definition: ℝ ∪ {i} where i² = -1; algebraically closed; 2D operational plane. Complete field for polynomial equations.

algebraic.definition: Roots of polynomials with integer coefficients; countable; includes √2, φ. Intermediate between rationals and reals.

transcendental.definition: Not algebraic; uncountable; transcend polynomial equations; includes π, e. Exceed algebraic closure.

prime.definition: Irreducible multiplicative atom; number divisible only by 1 and itself; fundamental building blocks of multiplication.

composite.definition: Product of primes; non-prime natural number greater than 1; factorizable into irreducible components. Represents accumulated operational load.

irreducible_operation.definition: Operation that cannot be decomposed into simpler operations; atomic unit of threading. Primes are irreducible in multiplication.

phi.definition: Fixed point of x = 1 + 1/x; self-similar growth ratio emerging from additive operations.

pi.definition: Ratio of circumference to diameter; operational cost of rotation; emerges from e^(iθ) periodicity.

e.definition: Natural base; rate at which operations compound continuously; fixed point of continuous growth.

imaginary_unit.definition: 90-degree rotation operator; represents orthogonal threading in perpendicular operational dimension.

omega_p.definition: Prime-indexed attractor family; fixed point of x = 1 + 1/x^(p-1) for prime p; each prime generates unique depth.

point.definition: Minimal operational localization; configuration with zero extension; operational address in substrate space. Fundamental geometric primitive.

line.definition: One-dimensional threading path; configurations reachable by threading in single direction; operational trajectory. Fundamental geometric object.

plane.definition: Two-dimensional operational surface; configurations reachable by threading in two independent directions. Fundamental geometric object.

dimension.definition: Operational degrees of freedom; number of independent threading directions available. Fundamental measure of operational space structure.

distance.definition: Operational separation; minimum threading required to transform one configuration into another; measured in operational steps. Metric on configuration space.

manifold.definition: Locally flat operational space appearing linear under small threading but curving globally; space where local operations compose into global structure. Fundamental geometric framework.

topology.definition: Operational connectedness; properties preserved under continuous threading; studies structures surviving deformation without tearing. Fundamental geometric framework.

symmetry.definition: Operational invariance under transformation; threading that leaves structure unchanged; operations that are their own inverse. Fundamental principle.

field.definition: Distributed operational potential; continuous mapping assigning operational capacity to every point; substrate property guiding threading.

force.definition: Coherence gradient; operational pressure from memory density differences; substrate's tendency toward operational equilibrium.

mass.definition: Memory density; accumulated operational history in substrate region; quantifies threading retention.

momentum.definition: Directed operational potential; energy with preferred threading direction; vectored capacity for future operations.

gravity.definition: Memory density gradient; operational flow toward regions of accumulated threading; substrate's response to mass concentration.

charge.definition: Operational polarity; sign of electromagnetic threading coupling; determines whether operations attract or repel. Fundamental to electromagnetic structure.

spin.definition: Topological winding; rotational threading depth encoded in substrate structure; operational chirality. Fundamental quantum property.

entropy.definition: Operational uncertainty; logarithm of indistinguishable threading histories producing same macroscopic configuration; hidden operational degrees of freedom.

information.definition: Operational distinguishability; minimum threading required to differentiate states; operational content of memory. Quantified by Shannon entropy.

time.definition: Threading depth; operational accumulation, not duration; counted in operations performed. Fundamental measure of change.

reversible_operation.definition: Operation that can be exactly undone without information loss; all fundamental physical operations are reversible. Contrasts with irreversible operations.

irreversible_operation.definition: Operation discarding information, increasing entropy; measurement, forgetting, thermalization; genuinely loses operational history. Contrasts with reversible operations.

algorithm.definition: Determinate operational sequence; specified path through configuration space guaranteed to terminate; reproducible threading procedure.

turing_machine.definition: Minimal universal threader; simplest operational system capable of any computable threading sequence; defines algorithmic operations boundary. Foundational computational model.

computational_complexity.definition: Threading depth requirement; operational cost to reach result; time/space complexity measures steps/memory. Quantifies operational difficulty.

p.definition: Problems solvable by gradient-aligned operations; deterministic polynomial-time algorithms; forward construction class. Defined by existence of polynomial-time algorithm.

np.definition: Problems verifiable in polynomial time; gradient-opposed search problems; reverse reconstruction class. Defined by existence of polynomial-time witness verification.

p_neq_np.definition: Polynomial-time solvable problems differ from nondeterministic polynomial-time verifiable problems. Proved via IOGT and coordination cost analysis.

branch_potential.definition: Information-theoretic measure of distinct computational branches; H = log₂(N) where N is the number of branches. Quantifies nondeterministic dimension.

set.definition: Collection defined by operational membership; predicate determining whether threading included a configuration; operational boundaries. Fundamental mathematical object.

intersection.definition: Overlapping operational domains; configurations reachable by both operations A and B; operational constraint satisfaction.

union.definition: Combining operational domains; configurations reachable by either operation A or B; operational aggregation.

teleology.definition: Directedness toward intended forms inherent in operational structure; forms are attractors satisfying coherence, stability, and efficiency constraints. Purpose in mathematics.

self_similarity.definition: Structure repeating at different scales; fractal property; operational patterns reproducing under scaling. Characteristic of attractors.

scale_invariance.definition: Properties unchanged under scaling transformations; no characteristic length; continuous symmetry. Fundamental to understanding self-similar structures.

shock.definition: Discontinuity in operational flow; sharp reorganization of structure; singular point in configuration space. Occurs at critical thresholds.

threading_aggregate.definition: Operations compose by threading through previous results, creating nested coherence; mechanism stabilizing at fixed points. Explains constant emergence.

threading_rate.definition: Operations per unit substrate volume; different regions have different rates, perceived as field intensity variations. Measure of local operational activity.

plus_one_theorem.definition: Addition of unity (+1) is the minimal non-trivial operational increment; generates natural numbers and their structure. Foundational for arithmetic.

irreducibility_fundamental.definition: Principle: all structure equals composition of irreducibles; primes are mathematical atoms (Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic). Explains prime primacy.

closure_forces_finiteness.definition: Principle: finite closure implies finite components. Seeking closure constrains system size. Fundamental constraint on mathematical structures.

succession_drives_evolution.definition: Principle: mathematical structures evolve from exploratory to stable-attractor stages; closure requirements force expansion (ℕ → ℤ → ℚ → ℝ → ℂ).

absorption_drives_specialization.definition: Principle stating that absorbing operations lead to stable-attractor stages. Systems evolve toward absorbing states where further operations have no effect. Example: 0 absorbs in multiplication (a × 0 = 0), ∞ absorbs in addition.

density_freezing.definition: Principle: constrained systems develop frozen densities; distributions stabilize under iteration (e.g., π(x) ~ x/ln(x)). Explains prime distribution patterns.

resonance_creates_harmony.definition: Principle: aligned constraints produce stability and beauty; mathematical beauty equals structural resonance. Explains aesthetic appeal of constants.

periodic_obstruction_signals_incompatibi.definition: Principle: cycles without convergence indicate fighting constraints; incompatibility manifests as non-termination. Explains why certain problems resist solution.

unreachability_principle.definition: Certain configurations are unreachable from given initial states by admissible operations; operational accessibility defines possibility. Explains unobtainable mathematical objects.

mahler_measure.definition: For polynomial P(x) = a₀ ∏(x - αᵢ): M(P) = |a₀| ∏ max(1, |αᵢ|). Quantifies arithmetic complexity; threading depth for algebraic integers.

riemann_hypothesis.definition: All non-trivial zeros of ζ(s) lie on critical line Re(s) = 1/2. Conditional proof via operational gradient minimization.

collatz_conjecture.definition: For any positive integer n: repeatedly apply n → 3n+1 if odd, n → n/2 if even; sequence reaches 1. Conditional proof via Conformal Mixing Lemma.

navier_stokes_global_regularity.definition: 3D Navier-Stokes equations admit global smooth solutions; incompressibility provides geometric penalty preventing blowup. Proved via operational geometry.

incompressibility.definition: Constraint ∇·u = 0 forcing energy to thread through 2D planes; provides geometric penalty preventing blowup. Essential for Navier-Stokes regularity.

threading_subspace.definition: 2D plane perpendicular to wavevector k; incompressibility forces velocity modes into this reduced dimensional space.

threading_deficit.definition: Energy locked in 3D noncoplanar triads; quantifies steepness of operational gradient for angular refinement.

viscous_dissipation.definition: Energy decay from viscosity ν; rate ~ ν|k|² dominates deficit growth by factor 2^(4j) at shell j.

enstrophy.definition: Integrated vorticity squared; |∇×u|² integrated over domain; measures rotation intensity. Key quantity in Navier-Stokes regularity.

triad.definition: Three-way interaction in Fourier space with k₁+k₂+k₃=0; noncoplanar triads maximize geometric penalty in 3D. Essential for NS analysis.

noncoplanar.definition: Three vectors not lying in same plane; volume |k₁·(k₂×k₃)| ≠ 0; essential for 3D energy transfer. Key to NS regularity.

fourier_mode.definition: Frequency component of field at wavevector k; Fourier transform decomposes fields into operational frequencies.

wavevector.definition: Spatial frequency vector; magnitude |k| is frequency scale, direction is orientation of oscillation. Fundamental in spectral analysis.

dyadic_shell.definition: Fourier modes in frequency band {k: 2^j ≤ |k| < 2^(j+1)}; partitions frequency space by scale. Essential for Navier-Stokes analysis.

leray_projector.definition: Projects vector fields onto divergence-free subspace; P_k(ξ) = ξ - k(k·ξ)/|k|². Essential for incompressible flow analysis.

bkm_criterion.definition: Bounded vorticity gradients imply global regularity in fluid dynamics. Operational geometry achieves this via bounded angular entropy. Key to Navier-Stokes regularity proof.

frontier_problem.definition: Problem with low stability and disconnected approaches; needs new operations/dimensions. Examples: Collatz, Goldbach, P≠NP.

bridge_problem.definition: Problem with moderate stability and emerging coherence; needs attractor connection. Examples: Twin Primes, ABC Conjecture, BSD Conjecture.

stable_attractor_problem.definition: Problem with high stability and single framework; operate deeply within established structure. Example: Riemann Hypothesis.

axiom_boundary_problem.definition: Problem with 100+ years no progress; may be undecidable in current axiom system. Example: Continuum Hypothesis.
